title: High-Performance Storage Server Connectivity
summary: This community is centered around a 'HIGH-PERFORMANCE STORAGE SERVER' identified as a NAS/SAN Target. It utilizes a robust network configuration featuring an 802.3ad LACP bond ('bond0_storage') for redundancy and load balancing across two physical Ethernet interfaces ('eno1', 'eno2'). All interfaces involved in the storage connectivity are configured with an MTU of 9000 bytes (Jumbo Frames), indicating a design for high-throughput, low-latency data transfer. A VLAN interface ('bond0.30') with ID 30 provides network access for the server within the 172.16.30.0/24 subnet, with the server's IP being 172.16.30.10. A next-hop gateway at 172.16.30.253 is also present within this subnet.
rating_explanation: This community involves a high-performance storage server, which is typically a critical component in any network infrastructure, supporting essential applications, databases, or virtualized environments. Its availability and performance are paramount for business operations. The use of LACP bonding and jumbo frames further emphasizes its role in handling high-throughput, low-latency traffic, making it a high-risk/high-importance asset.
findings: Dedicated high-performance storage server (NAS/SAN target) is a critical asset.
Utilizes LACP (802.3ad) bonding for interface redundancy and load balancing, enhancing availability.
Configured with Jumbo Frames (MTU 9000) across all relevant interfaces, indicating high-throughput requirements for storage traffic.
VLAN 30 is dedicated to this storage server's connectivity, suggesting network segmentation.
DHCPv4 is disabled on physical interfaces, implying static IP configuration, which is standard for servers.

title: Spine Router 02 - Core Connectivity
summary: This community describes 'SPINE ROUTER 02,' identified as a 'Redundant L3 Core, Node 2.' This device serves as a core routing component within the network, connecting various segments. It features three physical interfaces: 'eth_to_edge10' (10.200.2.2/30), 'eth_to_leaf3' (10.0.1.1/30), and 'eth_to_leaf6' (10.0.13.1/30). The interfaces connecting to 'leaf' devices ('eth_to_leaf3', 'eth_to_leaf6') are configured with Jumbo Frames (MTU 9000), indicating their role in high-bandwidth inter-router or router-to-access layer connectivity. The presence of a gateway IP 10.200.2.1 suggests a connection to an 'edge' network. This router is explicitly part of a redundant core infrastructure, implying high availability.
rating_explanation: As a 'Redundant L3 Core' router, this device is a critical part of the network's backbone. Its failure would severely impact inter-VLAN routing, external connectivity, and overall network performance. The 'redundant' designation implies it's part of a high-availability setup, but its individual importance remains very high. Jumbo frames on leaf connections suggest it handles significant internal network traffic, making it a high-impact component.
findings: Identified as a core L3 router, part of a redundant setup, crucial for network resilience.
Connects to 'leaf' devices (likely access or distribution layer switches) using point-to-point /30 subnets, typical in spine-leaf architectures.
Utilizes Jumbo Frames (MTU 9000) on interfaces connecting to leaf devices, indicating high-throughput internal routing requirements.
Also connects to an 'edge' network, suggesting external or perimeter connectivity, making it a gateway for certain traffic.
Part of a spine-leaf architecture, which is crucial for network scalability and performance.

title: Spine Router 01 - High Performance Core
summary: This community details 'SPINE ROUTER 01,' designated as a 'High Performance L3 Core, Node 1.' This device is a fundamental core routing component, likely working in conjunction with Spine Router 02 (Community 5) to form the network's backbone. It has three physical interfaces: 'eth_to_edge9' (10.200.1.2/30), 'eth_to_leaf4' (10.0.2.1/30), and 'eth_to_leaf5' (10.0.3.1/30). Similar to its counterpart, interfaces connecting to 'leaf' devices ('eth_to_leaf4', 'eth_to_leaf5') are configured with Jumbo Frames (MTU 9000), indicating a design for high-bandwidth internal routing. It connects to an 'edge' network (10.200.1.0/30) and has multiple next-hop gateway IPs (10.0.1.2, 10.0.2.2, 10.0.3.2, 10.200.1.1) and a destination network subnet (172.16.20.0/24) associated with it, highlighting its role in routing diverse traffic flows.
rating_explanation: As a 'High Performance L3 Core' router, this device is fundamental to the network's operation, handling inter-VLAN routing, external connectivity, and overall traffic forwarding. Its failure would have a severe impact on the entire network. The 'high performance' designation and jumbo frames on leaf connections underscore its critical role in handling substantial network traffic. It likely works in conjunction with Spine Router 02 for redundancy and load sharing, making it a high-impact component.
findings: Identified as a core L3 router, emphasizing 'high performance,' indicating its critical role in traffic forwarding.
Connects to 'leaf' devices using point-to-point /30 subnets, typical in spine-leaf architectures.
Utilizes Jumbo Frames (MTU 9000) on interfaces connecting to leaf devices, indicating high-throughput internal routing requirements.
Connects to an 'edge' network, suggesting external or perimeter connectivity, acting as a gateway.
Multiple next-hop gateway IPs suggest routing to various internal and potentially external segments, indicating complex routing responsibilities.
Routes traffic for the 172.16.20.0/24 destination network, confirming its role in specific network segment reachability.
Part of a spine-leaf architecture, which is crucial for network scalability and performance.
